Award.AwardTitle: In-situ Monitoring and Active Controls of Individual Nucleation and Crystal Growth through Nanoscale Mass Transport
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation. Professor Gangli Wang and his group members at Georgia State University develop new analytical methods providing knowledge of early-stage nucleation and subsequent crystal growth at greater time and spatial resolutions than is otherwise possible. High quality single crystals display chemical, physical, and mechanical properties, and have superb performance in practical applications in chemical, pharmaceutical and materials industries. Lack of capable methods to measure and to actively control the crystallization process has been a limit on the advance of fundamental research as well as practical applications. The capability to measure the dynamic process in-situ and thus to actively control crystal formation is expected to establish much-needed high throughput and high efficiency crystallization technology. The broader impacts are demonstrated in that the proposed aims advance the paradigm of crystallization. Students from underrepresented groups and from disadvantageous backgrounds in metro Atlanta gain first-hand knowledge and experiences through the grant activities.

The overarching goal of this proposal is to establish an electroanalytical methodology combined with optical imaging that enables in-situ monitoring and active controls of single nucleus formation and single crystal growth. Analytical platforms are being developed with optimized nanostructures and surface functionalities to spatially confine the formation and growth of a single nucleus at the earliest stage (molecular assembly) one at a time. The kinetics of a single crystal nucleus formation and growth, governed by local transport of the target molecules around the nucleus, are controlled externally via a programmed potential waveform. Active control of mass transport is another superior advantage over the passive diffusion mechanism adopted in conventional crystallization methods. Because the transport and assembly processes are associated with changes in ionic current signals as well as optical properties, in-situ monitoring and adjustments are performed to tailor the nucleation and growth kinetics of individual events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Crystals are integral parts in our life: ice is water crystals; diamond is a form of carbon crystals; and some therapeutic drugs are formulated into certain crystalline morphologies. From chemistry, biology, materials science to engineering, high quality crystals are widely pursued for fundamental research such as structure determination and drug design and development, as well as various industrial applications based on their exciting physicochemical and mechanical properties. A critical step in the formation of crystals is at early stage, namely the assembly of individual molecules or building blocks into crystal embryo or nucleus up to a favorable size. This dynamic heterogenous process is often referred as nucleation. Nucleation is widely regarded to govern the fate or quality of the crystals being synthesized, a dynamic process of tremendous technical challenge to study and ultimately to control precisely and accurately.

With the funding support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of Chemistry Division at NSF, a new method named NanoAC has been established to grow crystals one at a time, i.e. single entity. The unprecedented measurement capability and active controls at single entity levels are achieved through collective hard work of graduate students, undergraduate students and summer research fellows (NSF REU) together with the PI. The research is naturally integrated with teaching and mentoring and  outreaches conveniently to underrepresented students at Georgia State University and the greater Atlanta area. The new method combines electroanalytical methodology with optical imaging for in-situ multi-modal signal collections during the dynamic early-stage nucleation and subsequent crystal growth. The patterns of those signals, such as the changes in electrical current or light intensity over time, are correlated and established as signatures for several key phase transition steps during the crystallization processes. Those signatures are employed retrospectively as feedbacks to control the crystal syntheses in real time. Through both hardware fabrications and method/parameter development and optimization, the capability to measure and thus to actively control crystal formation at unprecedented single entity resolutions are demonstrated using prototype materials systems such as protein insulin, lysozyme and in-house synthesized atomically precise metal nanoclusters. In addition to the previous inaccessible fundamental knowledge at greater time and spatial resolutions, the ease-of-use method could shift the paradigm of classical crystallization and offer predictive insights to establish much-needed high throughput and high efficiency crystallization technology.
